Sheet

0. Background

Carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases are the primary contributors to global climate change. Since 1850, greenhouse gas emissions have been constantly on the rise. The World Bank maintains data between the years 1990-2019.

While the majority of nations have emission data available, there are a number of territories which are not included individually in the data set, and their data is presumed to be included in their administrators. Certain independent nations may be excluded for a portion of the time period due to a variety of socioeconomic factors. For example, Monaco is not included in the data at all while Mali is excluded between 1990 and 1999.

This report will begin by analyzing the data and how emissions change over time. It will explore why certain changes occur and what they may mean for the data.

1. Data Description

The data for this project are CO2e emissions by nation. While the data was originally sourced from The World Bank, the data is publically available below:

World Bank. "CO2 emissions (metric tons per capita)" World Development Indicators, The World Bank Group, 2020.

Additionally, a dataset containing region data was merged with the primary emissions data.

lukes. "ISO-3166 Country and Dependent Territories Lists with UN Regional Codes", 2022, GitHub repository, https://github.com/lukes/ISO-3166-Countries-with-Regional-Codes/commit/6741ae83a08ce1802d22849db0a944d99e254bae

The method of collection is not made clear by The World Bank, but they do cite their own source as ClimateWatch. The regional data was sourced from the United Nations Statistics and the International Organization for Standardization and taken from the above GitHub repository. The scope of the data is nations which report or have emissions measured between the years of 1990 and 2019.

Data Structure

In the case of this study, the observational units are each nation and the variables include year and emissions. There are several measurements made on each observational unit. The structure of the tidied data is below:

Table 1: variable descriptions and units for each variable in the dataset.

Name Variable Description Types Units of Measurement
year the year during which measurements were taken String Year
country independent nations which provide CO2e emissions data String Country
region continent on which a country is located String Continent
emissions CO2e emissions Numeric metric tons per capita

During the analysis, the raw emissions data was cleaned, merged with the regional data, and pivoted in order to have two columns for year and emissions, rather than a column for each year. The table below shows how the data was initially used, before being manipulated into other formats. It should be noted that North and South America are considered a single region known as Americas due to the United Nations' classification system.

Table 2: Example rows of tidied emissions data

region country year emissions
1 Asia Afghanistan 1990 0.191745
2 Africa Angola 1990 0.553662
3 Europe Albania 1990 1.819542
4 Europe Andorra 1990 7.521832
5 Asia United Arab Emirates 1990 30.195189

2. Methods

The initial exploratory analysis was performed in order to find any anomalies or interesting periods in the data. The data was first presented on a map, to see if any countries or regions experienced a significant change in emissions over time. Then the data was viewed as a time series of emissions by continent in order to see what the general trends are world wide. Finally, the anomalies discovered will be further investigated to determine if they can be explained in more depth.

3. Analysis

Change in Emissions by Decade

The data is first viewed on a wider scale to look at how it changes world wide. These choropleth maps display the change each decade in the data, with the exception of 2019, which is nine years later as there is no data available for 2020 at the time of this report being written.

Figure 1: Map of CO2e emissions worldwide over time. The varying CO2e emissions are represented on a green to red scale, with green representing the lowest reported values and red the highest.

There is a clear shift in the emissions of many countries in the graph above, particularly of those in Europe and Asia. In Eastern Europe, there was a sharp decline in emissions between 1990 and 2000. The rest of Europe saw a much slower decline which continued until 2019. In Asia, the reverse occurs and the region sees a gradual growth in reported emissions over the period. This change seems to be primarily propelled by Eastern Asia, with Southern Asia following exhibiting the same trend but at a slower pace.

Analysis of Emissions by Year

Now that there is a general sense of the trends taken in each region, the emissions can be viewed as a time series of how emissions change for each continent by year.

Figure 2: Change in CO2e Emissions by Continent (1990-2019)

The figure above supports the trends discovered in Figure 1. The emissions reported by Oceania remained relatively the same over time, but this is not the case elsewhere. Africa, the Americas, and Asia had an upwards trend between 1990 and 2019. Of these, Asia not only had the sharpest upwards trend but also higher reported emissions per capita each year than Africa or the Americas. Europe is the only region with a consistent downwards trend.

Additionally, it is interesting to note that the Americas experienced a spike in reported emissions between 2008 and 2009 which went back down by 2010. Conversely, an unusual drop in emissions can be seen in Europe, which also returns to normal between the same set of years.

Due to their higher emissions for each reported year, the continents of Asia and Europe will be investigated further, to see if the eight countries with the highest reported emissions can lend any insight. Following this, we will look at the change in emissions between 2008 and 2009.

Asia vs. Europe Over Time

Figure 3: Opposing Trends in the Eight Highest Average Nations (Asia vs. Europe)

Each line represents a country in the specified region which exhibited the greatest change between 1990 and 2019. In Asia, it can be seen that Qatar and Kuwait rose significantly during the late 1990s and early 2000s, but declined in recent years. China, Iran, South Korea, Malaysia, Oman, and Saudi Arabia have increased steadily over time.

In the case of Europe, these countries have often faced much more erratic decreases in per capita CO2e emissions. The former Soviet Socialist Republics, which include Estonia, Moldova, and Ukraine, all experienced rapid decreases in their emissions during the 1990s, before exhibiting more stable trends between 2000 and 2019. The Czech Republic, Denmark, the Slovak Republic, and the United Kingdom have all experienced a steady decline in per capita CO2e emissions, Luxembourg has experienced both the greatest decrease and increase of the represented countries. Luxembourg is an interesting case in the data as it may be susceptible to fluctuation due to the small size and population as well as open border policies from being a member of the European Union.

2008 to 2009

In Figure 2 between the years 2008 and 2009, is a sudden deviation in trend for the Americas and Europe. On first thought, it may be explainable by the Great Recession (2007-2009) but there must first be an investigation as to which nations contributed to the changes in each region.

Figure 4: Change in Emissions from 2008 to 2009

In the Americas bar graph, the nations with a change in emissions by at least two metric tons per capita. It can be seen that there was a fairly large rise in emissions by countries located in Central America and the Caribbean, despite the ongoing Great Recession. In Europe, the nations with a change in emissions of at least 1 metric ton per capita are displayed, and there is instead a decline in emissions. An initial explanation may be the Great Recession.

Figure 5:

pline

Figure 5 further emphasizes the trends between 2008 and 2010. The first chart, which displays nations in the Americas which saw a change in emissions by at least 0.50 metric tons per capita. Again, there was an increase in emissions in much of Central America and the Caribbean in 2009 which returned to close to previous levels by 2010. Canada, Jamaica, Trinidad and Tobago, and the United States recorded a decrease in emissions between 2008 and 2009, before an increase by 2010.

The second chart displays European countries with a change in emissions by at least 0.75 metric tons per capita. In the case of Europe, there are fewer nations which seem to decrease only to return to close to normal values. With the exception of Ireland and Spain, many of the countries shown returned to their pre-2009 levels by 2010. Both Ireland and Spain seemed to maintain a decreasing trend in 2010, rather than an increase. This may indicate that the recession did not affect them as it did other nations, or that the affects may have been more long lasting.

In conclusion, both Europe and Asia had the most extreme trends out of the data. Europe has trended consistently downwards, with a notable decrease during the 1990s which continued at a steady rate to 2019. Asia instead has steadily increased as a whole, only seeing a decrease during the 2008 recession. Upon investigation of the most significant changes in data between 2008 and 2010, the year 2009 represents an anomaly in the data, regardless of if they can be attributed to an increase or decrease in per capita emissions.

import pandas as pd
import altair as alt
from altair import datum
from vega_datasets import data

alt.data_transformers.disable_max_rows()
alt.themes.enable('vox')

# Importing the CO2 data
rawdata = pd.read_csv('CO2_emission.csv')

# Importing the region data
rawregdata = pd.read_csv('continents2.csv')

# Slicing the region data
loc_data = rawregdata.loc[
    :, ['alpha-3', 'country-code']
].rename(
    columns = {'country-code' : 'id'}
)

# Slicing the CO2 data and creating year/emissions columns
yearlydata = rawdata.loc[
    :, ~rawdata.columns.isin(
        ['Region', 'Indicator Name', '2019.1']
    )
].rename(
    columns = {'Country Name' : 'country', 
               'country_code' : 'alpha-3'}
).melt(
    id_vars = ['country', 'alpha-3'],
    var_name = 'year',
    value_name = 'emissions'
).round(decimals=3)

# Combining the year/emissions data with the local data
mapdata = pd.merge(
    yearlydata, loc_data, on='alpha-3'
).drop('alpha-3', axis=1).fillna(0)

md90 = mapdata[mapdata.year == '1990'] # Map data for 1990
md00 = mapdata[mapdata.year == '2000'] # Map data for 2000
md10 = mapdata[mapdata.year == '2010'] # Map data for 2010
md19 = mapdata[mapdata.year == '2019'] # Map data for 2019

# Nation information for the map
world = alt.topo_feature(data.world_110m.url, 'countries')

# Choropleth 1
p90 = alt.Chart(world).mark_geoshape(
    stroke='black', strokeWidth=0.15
).encode(
    color=alt.Color(
        'emissions:N', scale=alt.Scale(
            scheme='redyellowgreen', reverse=True
        ),
        legend=None
    ),
    tooltip=[
        alt.Tooltip('country:N', title='Country'),
        alt.Tooltip('emissions:Q', title='Emissions')
    ]
).transform_lookup(
    lookup='id',
    from_=alt.LookupData(
        md90, 'id', ['emissions', 'country']
    )
).transform_filter(
    datum.id!=10
).properties(
    title = '1990'

).project(
    'naturalEarth1'
)

# Choropleth 2
p00 = alt.Chart(world).mark_geoshape(
    stroke='black', strokeWidth=0.15
).encode(
    color=alt.Color(
        'emissions:N', scale=alt.Scale(
            scheme='redyellowgreen', reverse=True
        ),
        legend=None
    ),
    tooltip=[
        alt.Tooltip('country:N', title='Country'),
        alt.Tooltip('emissions:Q', title='Emissions')
    ]
).transform_lookup(
    lookup='id',
    from_=alt.LookupData(
        md00, 'id', ['emissions', 'country']
    )
).transform_filter(
    datum.id!=10
).properties(
    title = '2000'

).project(
    'naturalEarth1'
)

# Choropleth 3
p10 = alt.Chart(world).mark_geoshape(
    stroke='black', strokeWidth=0.15
).encode(
    color=alt.Color(
        'emissions:N', scale=alt.Scale(
            scheme='redyellowgreen', reverse=True
        ),
        legend=None
    ),
    tooltip=[
        alt.Tooltip('country:N', title='Country'),
        alt.Tooltip('emissions:Q', title='Emissions')
    ]
).transform_lookup(
    lookup='id',
    from_=alt.LookupData(
        md10, 'id', ['emissions', 'country']
    )
).transform_filter(
    datum.id!=10
).properties(
    title = '2010'

).project(
    'naturalEarth1'
)

# Choropleth 4
p19 = alt.Chart(world).mark_geoshape(
    stroke='black', strokeWidth=0.15
).encode(
    color=alt.Color(
        'emissions:N', scale=alt.Scale(
            scheme='redyellowgreen', reverse=True
        ),
        legend=None
    ),
    tooltip=[
        alt.Tooltip('country:N', title='Country'),
        alt.Tooltip('emissions:Q', title='Emissions')
    ]
).transform_lookup(
    lookup='id',
    from_=alt.LookupData(
        md19, 'id', ['emissions', 'country']
    )
).transform_filter(
    datum.id!=10
).properties(
    title = '2019'
).project(
    'naturalEarth1'
)

# Combinging the maps into one graphic FIGURE 1
final_map = ((p90 | p00) & (p10 | p19)).configure_view(
    strokeWidth=0
).configure_title(
    fontSize=12, anchor='start', offset=-30
)

# Regional data for next plot
regiondata = rawregdata.rename(
    columns = {'alpha-3' : 'country_code'}
).loc[:, ['country_code', 'region', 'sub-region']]

# CO2 data for next plot
co2data = pd.merge(
    rawdata, regiondata, on = 'country_code'
).rename( # Simplyfying the column names
    columns = {'Country Name' : 'country', 
               'Indicator Name' : 'emissions'} # 1 indicator
).drop(['Region', '2019.1'], axis = 1) 

# Creating year/emissions columns
yeardata = co2data.drop(
    ['country_code', 'emissions'], axis=1
).melt(
    id_vars = ['region', 'sub-region', 'country'],
    var_name = 'year',
    value_name = 'emissions'    
).dropna()

# Final dataset for FIGURE 2
regyear = yeardata.groupby(
    ['year', 'region']
).sum().reset_index().round(3)

# Color scheme for FIG2
dom = ['Africa', 'Americas', 'Asia', 'Europe', 'Oceania']
ran = ['#E33223', '#5C08AD', '#FF7D00', '#0E90EB', '#0FA907']

# Line plot of continental emissions over time
cont_time = alt.Chart(regyear).mark_line(
    point=alt.OverlayMarkDef()
).encode(
    x = alt.X('year:T', title=None),
    y = alt.Y('emissions:Q', title='CO2e Emissions per Capita'),
    color = alt.Color(
        'region', title=None, legend = alt.Legend(
            orient='bottom', title=None, columns=5
        ),
        scale = alt.Scale(domain=dom, range=ran)
    ),
    tooltip = [
        alt.Tooltip('year:T', title='Year', format='%Y'),
        alt.Tooltip('emissions:Q', title='Emissions')
    ]
).properties(
    width=800
)

# Initial data in order to find differences from 1990 to 2019
line_data = yeardata.copy()
line_asia = line_data[line_data.region == 'Asia']

# The nations with the highest differences in Asia
top_diff = yeardata.copy()
top_diff = top_diff[top_diff.year.isin(['1990', '2019'])].pivot(
    index = ['region', 'country'], columns = 'year', 
    values = 'emissions'
).reset_index().rename_axis(None, axis=1)

# Creating a column which contains the differences
top_diff['total_change'] = top_diff['2019'] - top_diff['1990']
top_diff = top_diff.loc[:, ['region', 'country', 'total_change']]

# Final data frame for FIG 3.1
top_diff_asia = top_diff.copy()[top_diff.region == 'Asia']
top_diff_asia = top_diff_asia.sort_values('total_change', ascending=False).head(8)

# Plot 3.1 top differences in Asia
pasia = alt.Chart(line_asia[line_asia.country.isin(top_diff_asia.country)]).mark_line(
    point=alt.OverlayMarkDef()
).encode(
    x = alt.X('year:T', title=None),
    y = alt.Y('emissions:Q', title='CO2e Emissions per Capita'),
    color = alt.Color(
        'country', scale = alt.Scale(scheme='set2'), 
        legend = alt.Legend(
            orient='bottom', title=None, columns=4
        )
    ),
    tooltip = [
        alt.Tooltip('country:N', title='Country'),
        alt.Tooltip('year:T', title='Year', format='%Y'),
        alt.Tooltip('emissions:Q', title='Emissions', format=',.3f')
    ]
).properties(title='Asia', width=400)

# Initial data frame for FIG 3.2
line_euro = line_data[line_data.region == 'Europe']

# Top differences in Europe
top_diff_euro = top_diff.copy()[top_diff.region == 'Europe']
top_diff_euro = top_diff_euro.sort_values('total_change').head(8)

# Plot 3.2 top differences in Europe
peurope = alt.Chart(line_euro[line_euro.country.isin(top_diff_euro.country)]).mark_line(
    point=alt.OverlayMarkDef()
).encode(
    x = alt.X('year:T', title=None),
    y = alt.Y('emissions:Q', title='CO2e Emissions per Capita',
              scale=alt.Scale(zero=False)),
    color = alt.Color(
        'country', scale = alt.Scale(scheme='set2'), 
        legend = alt.Legend(
            orient='bottom', title=None, columns=4
        )
    ),
    tooltip = [
        alt.Tooltip('country:N', title='Country'),
        alt.Tooltip('year:T', title='Year', format='%Y'),
        alt.Tooltip('emissions:Q', title='Emissions', format=',.3f')
    ]
).properties(title='Europe', width=400)

# FIGURE 3 Top changes in Asia and Europe
asiavseurope = (pasia | peurope).resolve_scale(
    color='independent'
).configure_view(
    stroke=None
).configure_title(
    fontSize=12, anchor='start'
)

# Differences between 2008 and 2009
diff = yeardata.copy()
diff = diff[diff.year.isin(['2008', '2009'])].pivot(
    index = ['region', 'country'], columns = 'year', 
    values = 'emissions'
).reset_index().rename_axis(None, axis=1)

# Finding the difference column
diff['diff'] = diff['2009'] - diff['2008']
diff = diff.loc[:, ['region', 'country', 'diff']]

# Differences in America
diff_america = diff[diff.region == 'Americas'].drop('region', axis=1)

# Differences in Europe
diff_europe = diff[diff.region == 'Europe'].drop('region', axis=1)

# Difference graphic for Americas
pdiff1 = alt.Chart(
    diff_america[diff_america['diff'].abs() > 2]
).mark_bar(color = '#CC0000').encode(
    x = alt.X('diff', title='Emissions Change'),
    y = alt.Y('country', title=None)
).properties(
    width = 395, height = 300, title='Americas'
)

# Difference graphic for Europe
pdiff2 = alt.Chart(
    diff_europe[diff_europe['diff'].abs() > 1]
).mark_bar(color='#0A9F00').encode(
    x = alt.X('diff', title='Emissions Change'),
    y = alt.Y('country', title=None)
).properties(
    width = 325, height = 300, title='Europe'
)

# FIGURE 4 Differences between 2008 to 2009
pdiff = (pdiff1 | pdiff2).configure_title(anchor='start', fontSize=10)

diff_america = diff_america[diff_america['diff'].abs() > 0.5]

line_diff1 = yearlydata[
    yearlydata.country.isin(diff_america.country)
]

diff_europe = diff_europe[diff_europe['diff'].abs() > 0.75]

line_diff2 = yearlydata[
        yearlydata.country.isin(diff_europe.country)
]

line_diff1.loc[:, 'year'] = line_diff1['year'].astype(int)

# Figure 5.1 line chart tracking changes from 2008 to 2009 to 2010
pline1 = alt.Chart(line_diff1).mark_line(
    point=alt.OverlayMarkDef()
).encode(
    x = alt.X('year:O', title='Year'),
    y = alt.Y('emissions', title='CO2e Emissions (metric tons per capita)'),
    color = alt.Color(
        'country', scale=alt.Scale(scheme='tableau20'),
        legend = alt.Legend(
            orient='bottom', title=None, columns=4
        )
    ),
    tooltip = [alt.Tooltip('emissions', title='Emissions'),
               alt.Tooltip('country', title='Country')]
).properties(
    width=400
).transform_filter(
    alt.FieldRangePredicate(field='year', range=[2008, 2010])
)

line_diff2.loc[:, 'year'] = line_diff2['year'].astype(int)

# Figure 5.2 line chart tracking changes from 2008 to 2009 to 2010
pline2 = alt.Chart(line_diff2).mark_line(
    point=alt.OverlayMarkDef()
).encode(
    x = alt.X('year:O', title='Year'),
    y = alt.Y('emissions', title='CO2e Emissions (metric tons per capita)'),
    color = alt.Color(
        'country', scale=alt.Scale(scheme='tableau20'),
        legend = alt.Legend(
            orient='bottom', title=None, columns = 4
        )
    ),
    tooltip = [alt.Tooltip('emissions', title='Emissions'),
               alt.Tooltip('country', title='Country')]
).properties(
    width=400
).transform_filter(
    alt.FieldRangePredicate(field='year', range=[2008, 2010])
)

# Figure 5 line chart
pline = (pline1 | pline2).resolve_scale(
    color='independent'
).configure_view(
    stroke=None
).configure_title(
    fontSize=12, anchor='start'
).configure_axisX(labelAngle=0)
